lines.text: INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE
R.J.Reynolds Tobacco Company
RJR
To
: Mr. M. D. Shannon
: L. Whit Peterson
From
Subject: Glass Fiber Specifications
Confirming our prior conversation, we continue to have concerns
regarding Section E of the Glass Fiber Specification. This section con-
tains specific restrictions regarding sampling of shipments, including
limitations on the number of rolls that can be sampled, along with the num-
ber of defective rolls required prior to rejection. Once specifications
have been established, selection of sampling procedures to administer these
specifications falls within the domain of Quality Assurance. The latitude
to frequently adjust sample levels in accordance with quality of materials
is essentia] to an effective inspection program.
The sampling plan included in the current specification is taken
directly from Mil. Stds. - 1osD. Under this plan, risk against random
sampling error is weighted heavily in favor of the supplier. For example,
if io0 shipments were made which contained loz defective material, we would
expect to accept over 60 of them. In view of the current status of glass
development and the critical nature of the component, we feel this risk is
unacceptable. lt is recommended this section be deleted from the specifi-
cation, and the supplier encouraged to concentrate on controlling produc-
tion within tolerances, rather than relying upon a specified level of
non-conforming material.
L. Whit Peterson
LWP/rv
xc:
Mr. Lucien l. Bass, I1] ~
Mr. Ron S. Beatty
Ms. Regina delacy
Mr. D. C. Straka
No.366By.2u6

full_text:
INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE
R.J.Reynolds Tobacco Company
RJR
July 23, 1986
To
: Mr. M. D. Shannon
: L. Whit Peterson
From
Subject: Glass Fiber Specifications
Confirming our prior conversation, we continue to have concerns
regarding Section E of the Glass Fiber Specification. This section con-
tains specific restrictions regarding sampling of shipments, including
limitations on the number of rolls that can be sampled, along with the num-
ber of defective rolls required prior to rejection. Once specifications
have been established, selection of sampling procedures to administer these
specifications falls within the domain of Quality Assurance. The latitude
to frequently adjust sample levels in accordance with quality of materials
is essentia] to an effective inspection program.
The sampling plan included in the current specification is taken
directly from Mil. Stds. - 1osD. Under this plan, risk against random
sampling error is weighted heavily in favor of the supplier. For example,
if io0 shipments were made which contained loz defective material, we would
expect to accept over 60 of them. In view of the current status of glass
development and the critical nature of the component, we feel this risk is
unacceptable. lt is recommended this section be deleted from the specifi-
cation, and the supplier encouraged to concentrate on controlling produc-
tion within tolerances, rather than relying upon a specified level of
non-conforming material.
L. Whit Peterson
LWP/rv
